images.text: This tool is based on the reproduction in SMD with modern components of a circuit published on "Nuova Elettronica" magazine. It allows to measure the ESR (Equivalent Serie Resistance) of electrolytic capacitors, to test their degradation state over time.
reference table with standard values, measured on worst case (external link)

list: electronics: preassembled circuit, switch, potentiometer, leds, 9V battery snap;
a cheap multimeter, model YX-1000A (sold in chinese/dollar stores);
screws to close box (10 self-tapping screws, M2.3x6);
various tools: tweezers, wire strippers, screwdriver;

paragraphs.subheader:
Notes

(*) you can purchase the kit in various versions:
list: option A electronics only: you will only be provided with the printed circuit board and accessory components (LEDs, potentiometer, switch, 9V battery snap), excluding the YX-1000A multimeter. Useful if you want to use your own box, or print the box yourself with your 3D printer, and you already have an YX-1000A multimeter (or another millammeter);
option B electronics + box (DIY assembly): all the electronics (printed circuit board, LEDs, potentiometer, switch, snap for 9V battery) and the 3D printed box (you need to assemble it by yourself);

option C electronics + box + YX-1000A multimeter (DIY assembly): all the electronics (printed circuit board, LEDs, potentiometer, switch, snap for 9V battery), the 3D printed box, and the YX-1000A multimeter (you need to assemble it by yourself);
option D complete tool (pre-assembled): ready-to-use, already pre-assembled tool in the 3D printed box, including the milliammeter;
paragraphs.footer: In any case, the 9V battery is excluded

paragraphs.subheader:
(**) model files for 3D printing of box are freely downloadable from here:

steps.header: taking all necessary parts from multimeter

images.text: open the multimeter removing the screw on the back
cut both milliammeter wires from the circuit
take out the circuit
cut the upper part containing the instrument with an hand saw (pay attention to the wires)
detail of cutting
remove the plastic parts of the old battery case from the back of the instrument
mark a 9mm strip at the bottom of the circuit
cut the bottom strip of the circuit board with the hand saw
detail of the circuit after cutting
unsolder the two diodes, and solder two wires onto the test lead bushings

steps.header: 1. assembly of the test lead bushings

images.text: insert the previously cutted PCB strip with the bushings into the box, pushing the bushings into the holes until they touch the plastic, then secure the locking bracket with two screws, letting the wires come out of the two slots

insert the power switch and the two LEDs. NOTE: One of the LEDs has a resistor and must be inserted into the socket marked with 'on'. Optional: If the LEDs are not locked into place, you can secure them with a drop of glue.
solder three wires onto the potentiometer pins, attach it to the front of the box, and add the knob
add the snap for the 9V battery, cutting the red wire at the switch, and soldering it to its terminals
details of connections
solder the potentiometer wires to the circuit on the R21 pads, following the diagram in the figure
solder the "short" LED wires to the LED1 pads (respecting the polarity) and the wires of test lead terminals to CN2
solder together the two red wires and the two black wires coming from the battery and the "power" LED on the CN1 pads, respecting the indicated polarity
then solder the two wires coming from the milliammeter on CN3
fix the circuit to the box using 3 screws
close the back cover with the four screws in the corners, insert the battery and close the battery compartment with another screw
If, by short-circuiting the probes, you should see the needle move to the left, you will simply need to invert the connection of the two milliammeter wires on the printed circuit board

by keeping the leads short-circuited and rotating the potentiometer clockwise, you should see the needle move to the right. If the needle moves to the left, simply reverse the connections of the two outer pins of the potentiometer

steps.header: 1. power on the tool and calibrate

images.text: keeping the probes short-circuited, rotate the potentiometer until the instrument needle reaches 0 (to the right)

steps.subheader:
connect the test leads to the capacitor's leads. The lower the resistance measured (the needle is fully to the right), the better the capacitor. The photos show a measurement of a visibly damaged capacitor and a new one.
NOTE: The measurement can also be performed on capacitors soldered to a printed circuit board (it is not necessary to remove them).
